tit.e: Written Appointments among the Samurai Class (Kantojo)

sen.j: 官途状（かんとじょう）とは、室町時代以降、主君が武功を挙げた家臣に対して特定の官職を私称することを許した書状のことである。
sen.e: Kantojo (官途状) is a letter which was used after the Muromachi period which stated, that a vassal who distinguished himself in a battle was allowed by his lord to use a specific government post as his private name.

sen.j: 官途書出、受領書出とも。
sen.e: It is also known as kanto no kakidashi (官途書出) or juryo no kakidashi (受領書出).

sen.j: 室町時代、守護大名の間では自らの家臣に対して、武官や国守の官名を私称することを許す慣行が生まれた。
sen.e: In the Muromachi period it became a customary practice among shugo daimyo that their vassals were allowed to call themselves after the official position or title of the military officer or the governor of the province.

This is called juryomei (受領名).

sen.cmt: 漢字削除しました。時制。

sen.j: また、その受領名を名乗ることを許すために主君から家臣に発給された書状が官途状といった。
sen.e: The permission to be called with a juryomei was issued by a letter by the lord to his vassal and this is called kantojo (官途状).
The permission to be called with a juryomei was issued as a letter by the lord to his vassal, which was called kantojo.
sen.cmt: 漢字削除しました。時制。
sen.e: The permission to be called with a juryomei was issued as a letter by the lord to his vassal, which was called kantojo.

sen.j: 官途状は領土の加増などと並ぶ、恩賞のひとつとしての役割を果たした。
sen.e: Kantojo functioned as one of the reward grants (恩賞), equal to an increase in territory.
Kantojo functioned as one of the reward grants, similar to increase in territory.

sen.j: そもそも、律令制の観点からいえば、これは朝廷の預かり知らぬものであり、守護大名とその家臣の間での私称に過ぎず、本来ならば不当ともいえる慣行であった。
sen.e: In the first place one can say it was essentially an invalid practice as it was no more than a private name between a vassal and his shugo daimyo and from the point of Ritsuryo law, the Imperial Court didn't know how to handle it.
In the first place, one can say it was essentially an invalid practice as it was no more than a private name between a vassal and his shugo daimyo, and was not under control of the Imperial Court.
sen.cmt: 「預かり知らぬ」は「管理下にない」と訳しました。
sen.e: In the first place, one can say it was essentially an invalid practice as it was no more than a private name between a vassal and his shugo daimyo, and was not under control of the Imperial Court.

sen.j: しかし、室町時代はとかく守護の力も強く、武士が中心の社会であり、こうした慣行が取り締まられることはなかった。
sen.e: But this customary practice could not be controlled as he power of the provincial military governors (shugo) grew and samurai played a central part in society. During and after the Sengoku period Kantojo was often used as a reward for military exploits.
But this customary practice was not controlled as provincial military governors (shugo) were influential and samurai played a central role in society.
sen.cmt: 訳文が2文になっていたので、分割しました。一原文一訳文の例外対処。
sen.e: But this customary practice was not controlled as provincial military governors (shugo) were influential and samurai played a central role in society.

sen.j: 戦国時代_(日本)を通じて官途状が武功の恩賞として多用された。
sen.e: During and after the Sengoku period, Kantojo was often used as a reward for military exploits.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処。カンマ追加。
sen.e: During and after the Sengoku period, Kantojo was often used as a reward for military exploits.

sen.j: しかし、さすがに朝廷や幕府など公式な場で用いるわけにはいかず、官途私称を憚る目的から、正式な官途名を工夫して、略して称する習慣が生まれた。
sen.e: But as might be expected such name could not be used at official places like the Imperial Court or the Shogunate, so with the intention of taking the name of a government post openly, a custom was born to call oneself after an official government post which was abbreviated and changed in a congenial way, this was the derivation of taking names like hyakkan na (百官名) and Azuma hyakkan (東百官) which use spread among the samurai.

As might be expected, however, such name could not be used at official places like the Imperial Court or the bakufu (Japanese feudal government), so with the intention to avoid privately using the government post names, a custom was born to use abbreviations of official government posts.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処。
sen.e: As might be expected, however, such name could not be used at official places like the Imperial Court or the bakufu (Japanese feudal government), so with the intention to avoid privately using the government post names, a custom was born to use abbreviations of official government posts.

sen.j: これが武士の間で広まり百官名、東百官という名乗りに派生していくこととなった。
sen.e: It became popular among samurai and resulted in using hyakkan na and Azuma hyakkan.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処。原文の意味に即して修正しました。
sen.e: It became popular among samurai and resulted in using hyakkan na and Azuma hyakkan.

sen.j: 江戸時代になると、中世末に一度没落し大名の地位を失った武士の家系などで、主に名主となって農村に残った旧臣たちに対して、官途状を発給する習慣が残った。
sen.e: With the beginning of the Edo period Daimyo of samurai descent who lost their position at one time at the end of the Medieval Period became headman and kept on issuing Kantojo to their old retainers, who stayed behind in the village.

After the Edo period, the custom remained among samurai families who once lost the position of daimyo during the end of mediaeval period to issue Kantojo mainly to their old retainer who stayed in villages.
sen.cmt: 原文の意味に即して修正しました。
